{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3720511,"name":"Bill Bagshaw","username":"BMLSS","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-21T18:40:33.253Z","cooked":"

I have been trying to use TrajectoryGenerator to get the Rev MaxSwerve base code to be more functional, and I have found that I can’t get a Trajectory to rotate the robot more than 90 degrees in a single trajectories. Is this a bug?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-08-21T19:07:43.665Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":141,"readers_count":140,"score":103.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505517,"topic_slug":"can-wpilibs-trajectorygenerator-be-used-to-get-a-rotation-of-more-than-90-degrees","display_username":"Bill Bagshaw","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50591,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-wpilibs-trajectorygenerator-be-used-to-get-a-rotation-of-more-than-90-degrees/505517/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3720528,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-21T19:25:50.170Z","cooked":"

TrajectoryGenerator can generate trajectories with 180° turns, but they have to follow an arc (albeit a narrow one) instead of turning in-place.

TrajectoryGenerator was designed and written in 2020 when differential drives were the most common drivetrain by far, and COTS swerve hadn’t taken off yet. It’s not recommended for swerve (or robots in general at this point) due to inherent design limitations that modern alternatives don’t have. Use PathPlanner (spline trajectories with constraints and optional on-the-fly generation) or Choreo (trajectory optimization) instead.

Why TrajectoryGenerator is bad in modern FRC

No turn-in-place trajectories

TrajectoryGenerator uses splines to encode the trajectory, and those are natively defined by curvature since they’re interpolating polynomials. Splines can’t encode a turn-in-place trajectory because the angular velocity is ill-defined. ω = vκ where ω is angular velocity, v is linear velocity, and κ is curvature. For an in-place rotation, v = 0 and κ = ∞, which isn’t enough information to uniquely define an angular velocity.

We considered handling coincident poses with different headings separately by generating a heading profile between them, but we’d have to add angular velocity/acceleration constraints to TrajectoryConfig since the existing curvature-based constraint system wouldn’t work.

In the end, we decided not to implement the extra complexity.

No independent heading profile

TrajectoryGenerator was designed under the assumption that the velocity vector always pointed in the same direction as the heading, because differential drives can’t move sideways. Swerve drives, on the other hand, can have a separate heading profile since they have an extra degree of freedom. Retrofitting a heading profile generator onto TrajectoryGenerator in a way that obeyed drivetrain constraints seemed unrealistic.

Thank you for your very informative answer. A work-around for me might have been to use the quinitic splines, but I will take your advice to use Choreo or PathPlanner.
I was trying to use minimal code for teaching, but it looks like I will need this addition code layer. Thanks.

BMLSS:

A work-around for me might have been to use the quinitic splines

All splines have the same limitations regardless of order.

Yes, but a 180 degree turn can be broken up into three doable 60 degree turns. ( start pose, list of two translations, end pose becomes a list of 4 poses)
Once again, thank you for your valuable time

Again:

calcmogul:

TrajectoryGenerator can generate trajectories with 180° turns, but they have to follow an arc (albeit a narrow one) instead of turning in-place.

This code successfully generates a cubic spline trajectory that executes a narrow 180° turn:

    var traj =
        TrajectoryGenerator.generateTrajectory(
            Pose2d.kZero, List.of(), new Pose2d(0, 0.1, Rotation2d.kPi),
            new TrajectoryConfig(feetToMeters(12), feetToMeters(12)));

The first pose is at the origin and pointing in the +x direction, and the second pose is offset by 0.1 m along the y-axis and pointing in the -x direction. Make sure you didn’t line up your poses along the initial heading direction like the following code, since that’ll produce a malformed spline and fail to generate.

    var traj =
        TrajectoryGenerator.generateTrajectory(
            Pose2d.kZero, List.of(), new Pose2d(0.1, 0, Rotation2d.kPi),
            new TrajectoryConfig(feetToMeters(12), feetToMeters(12)));

Thank you. I just found my error- I had the turning velocity turned down too much for the turn to work. I increased my max angular velocity and my max angular acceleration, and I got my 180 turn over my path.

This is what I had in the RobotContainer
// An example trajectory to follow. All units in meters.
Trajectory exampleTrajectory = TrajectoryGenerator.generateTrajectory(
List.of(DriveConstants.kHome2dPose,
DriveConstants.kHomeToGoalWay1,
DriveConstants.kHomeToGoalWay2,
DriveConstants.kGoal2dPose),
config);

// Key Locations ( in the constants file)
public static final Pose2d kHome2dPose = new Pose2d(12.26,1.92, new Rotation2d(Units.degreesToRadians(-57)));
public static final Pose2d kHomeToGoalWay1 = new Pose2d(13.40,1.76,new Rotation2d(Units.degreesToRadians(20)));
public static final Pose2d kHomeToGoalWay2 = new Pose2d(14.05,2.28,new Rotation2d(Units.degreesToRadians(90)));
public static final Pose2d kGoal2dPose = new Pose2d(13.88,2.57, new Rotation2d(Units.degreesToRadians(120.0)));
